title: Synthetic Recap
body:
By The Associated Press

NEW YORK — In a virtuoso performance for the ages, Michael Jordan dropped a stunning 51 points, but it was his supporting cast that delivered the final, decisive blows as the Chicago Bulls outlasted the Detroit Pistons, 105-94, at Madison Square Garden.

From the opening tip, this was the Jordan Show. He was simply unstoppable, slicing through the Detroit defense with an array of impossible fadeaways and relentless drives to the basket. The Pistons, despite 21 points from Grant Hill and a double-double of 17 points and 14 rebounds from Otis Thorpe, had no answer for the game’s premier player. Jordan’s 51-point explosion was the entire narrative for three quarters, a one-man war against a formidable opponent.

But with the game on the line, the Knicks’ renowned toughness took over. Patrick Ewing, who finished with 22 points and 10 rebounds, anchored the paint, while the backcourt of John Starks and Charlie Ward provided the knockout punch. Starks ignited the Garden crowd with a clutch three-pointer to stretch the lead, and Ward iced the game with a cold-blooded triple of his own, part of his 15-point night.

In the end, Jordan’s historic night—a brilliant, singular effort—was ultimately overshadowed by a complete team victory. The Knicks proved that even the greatest individual performance can be vanquished by a collective will, securing a hard-fought triumph on their home floor.
